title: Phage-ligand technology
text:
The Phage-ligand technology is a technology to detect, bind and remove <a href="bacteria">bacteria</a> and <a href="bacterial%20toxin">bacterial toxin</a>s by using highly specific <a href="bacteriophage">bacteriophage</a> derived proteins.
Origins.
The <a href="Bacteriophages%23Attachment%20and%20penetration">host recognition of bacteriophages</a> occur via bacteria-binding proteins that have strong binding affinities to specific protein or <a href="carbohydrate">carbohydrate</a> structures on the surface of the bacterial host. At the end of the <a href="Bacteriophages%23Replication">infection life cycle</a> the bacteria-lysing <a href="Endolysin">Endolysin</a> is synthesized and degrades the bacterial <a href="peptidoglycan">peptidoglycan</a> <a href="cell%20wall">cell wall</a>, resulting in <a href="lysis">lysis</a> (and therefore killing) of the bacterial cell.
Applications.
Bacteriophage derived proteins are used for detection and removal of bacteria and bacterial components (especially <a href="Endotoxins%23Endotoxin%20contamination">endotoxin contaminations</a>) in pharmaceutical and biological products, human diagnostics, food, and <a href="Decolonization%20%28medicine%29">decolonization</a> of bacteria causing <a href="nosocomial%20infections">nosocomial infections</a> (e.g. <a href="Methicillin-resistant%20Staphylococcus%20aureus">MRSA</a>). 
Protein modifications allow the <a href="biotechnological">biotechnological</a> adaption to specific requirements.
